description.narrative:
In November 2017, at the UNFCCC COP23 meeting in Bonn, Australia announced a $6 million initiative to support efforts to protect and manage blue carbon ecosystems in the Pacific.
This initiative aims to strengthen blue carbon expertise and data in the Pacific; support the integration of blue carbon into national greenhouse gas accounting and climate policy; and encourage public and private sector investment in blue carbon restoration and conservation projects.
Blue carbon ecosystems – mangroves, tidal marshes and seagrasses – capture more carbon per square metre than almost any other ecosystem and play an important role as fisheries breeding grounds and natural buffers against coastal erosion from rising seas.
